<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.02869</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02869</id><created>2018-01-09</created><updated>2018-01-22</updated><authors><author><keyname>Higuchi</keyname><forenames>Koki</forenames></author><author><keyname>Machida</keyname><forenames>Masahiro N.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Susa</keyname><forenames>Hajime</forenames></author></authors><title>Evolution of Magnetic Fields in Collapsing Star-forming Clouds under
  Different Environments</title><categories>astro-ph.SR astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>18 pages; accepted for publication in MNRAS</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty046</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  In nearby star-forming clouds, amplification and dissipation of the magnetic
field are known to play crucial roles in the star-formation process. The
star-forming environment varies from place to place and era to era in galaxies.
In the present study, amplification and dissipation of magnetic fields in
star-forming clouds are investigated under different environments using
magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) simulations. We consider various star-forming
environments in combination with the metallicity and the ionization strength,
and prepare prestellar clouds having two different mass-to-flux ratios. We
calculate the cloud collapse until protostar formation using ideal and
non-ideal (inclusion and exclusion of Ohmic dissipation and ambipolar
diffusion) MHD calculations to investigate the evolution of the magnetic field.
We perform 288 runs in total and show the diversity of the density range within
which the magnetic field effectively dissipates, depending on the environment.
In addition, the dominant dissipation process (Ohmic dissipation or ambipolar
diffusion) is shown to strongly depend on the star-forming environment.
Especially, for the primordial case, magnetic field rarely dissipates without
ionization source, while it efficiently dissipates when very weak ionization
sources exist in the surrounding environment. The results of the present study
help to clarify star formation in various environments.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.02891</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>

<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02891</id><created>2018-01-09</created><updated>2018-01-10</updated><authors><author><keyname>Ruggeri</keyname><forenames>Rossana</forenames></author><author><keyname>Percival</keyname><forenames>Will J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Marin</keyname><forenames>Hector Gil</forenames></author><author><keyname>Beutler</keyname><forenames>Florian</forenames></author><author><keyname>Mueller</keyname><forenames>Eva Maria</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhu</keyname><forenames>Fangzhou</forenames></author><author><keyname>Padmanabhan</keyname><forenames>Nikhil</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhao</keyname><forenames>Gong-Bo</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zarrouk</keyname><forenames>Pauline</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sanchez</keyname><forenames>Ariel G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bautista</keyname><forenames>Julian</forenames></author><author><keyname>Brinkmann</keyname><forenames>Jonathan</forenames></author><author><keyname>Brownstein</keyname><forenames>Joel R.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Baumgarten</keyname><forenames>Falk</forenames></author><author><keyname>Chuang</keyname><forenames>Chia Hsun</forenames></author><author><keyname>Dawson</keyname><forenames>Kyle</forenames></author><author><keyname>Seo</keyname><forenames>Hee Jong</forenames></author><author><keyname>Tojeiro</keyname><forenames>Rita</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhao</keyname><forenames>Cheng</forenames></author></authors><title>The clustering of the SDSS-IV extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic
  Survey DR14 quasar sample: measuring the evolution of the growth rate using
  redshift space distortions between redshift 0.8 and 2.2</title><categories>astro-ph.CO</categories><comments>11 pages</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We measure the growth rate and its evolution using the anisotropic clustering
of the extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS) Data Release 14
(DR14) quasar sample, which includes $148\,659$ quasars covering the wide
redshift range of $0.8 &lt; z &lt; 2.2$ and a sky area of $2112.90$ $\rm deg^2$. To
optimise measurements we deploy a redshift-dependent weighting scheme, which
allows us to avoid binning, and perform the data analysis consistently
including the redshift evolution across the sample. We perform the analysis in
Fourier space, and use the redshift evolving power spectrum multipoles to
measure the redshift space distortion parameter $f\sigma_8$ and parameters
controlling the anisotropic projection of the cosmological perturbations. We
measure $f \sigma_8(z=1.52)=0.43 \pm 0.05 $ and $df\sigma_8/dz (z=1.52)= - 0.16
\pm 0.08$, consistent with the expectation for a $\Lambda$CDM cosmology as
constrained by the Planck experiment.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.02898</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-10</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02898</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Lazio</keyname><forenames>T. Joseph W.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Bhaskaran</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Cutler</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Folkner</keyname><forenames>W. M.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Park</keyname><forenames>R. S.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Ellis</keyname><forenames>J. A.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, West Virginia University</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Ely</keyname><forenames>T.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Taylor</keyname><forenames>S. R.</forenames><affiliation>California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Vallisneri</keyname><forenames>M.</forenames><affiliation>Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology</affiliation></author></authors><title>Solar System Ephemerides, Pulsar Timing, Gravitational Waves, and
  Navigation</title><categories>astro-ph.IM astro-ph.CO astro-ph.EP</categories><comments>Four pages, 3 figures; to appear in the proceedings of IAU Symposium
  337: Pulsar Astrophysics - The Next 50 Years, eds. P. Weltevrede, B. B. P.
  Perera, L. Levin Preston &amp; S. Sanidas; see also http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/ and
  arXiv:1801.02617</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  In-spiraling supermassive black holes should emit gravitational waves, which
would produce characteristic distortions in the time of arrival residuals from
millisecond pulsars. Multiple national and regional consortia have constructed
pulsar timing arrays by precise timing of different sets of millisecond
pulsars. An essential aspect of precision timing is the transfer of the times
of arrival to a (quasi-)inertial frame, conventionally the solar system
barycenter. The barycenter is determined from the knowledge of the planetary
masses and orbits, which has been refined over the past 50 years by multiple
spacecraft. Within the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational
Waves (NANOGrav), uncertainties on the solar system barycenter are emerging as
an important element of the NANOGrav noise budget. We describe what is known
about the solar system barycenter, touch upon how uncertainties in it affect
gravitational wave studies with pulsar timing arrays, and consider future
trends in spacecraft navigation.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.02924</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02924</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Shultz</keyname><forenames>M. E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wade</keyname><forenames>G. A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Rivinius</keyname><forenames>Th.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Neiner</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Alecian</keyname><forenames>E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bohlender</keyname><forenames>D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Monin</keyname><forenames>D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sikora</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>MiMeS</keyname><forenames>the</forenames></author><author><keyname>Collaborations</keyname><forenames>BinaMIcS</forenames></author></authors><title>The Magnetic Early B-type Stars I: Magnetometry and Rotation</title><categories>astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>38 pages, 47 figures, accepted for publication in MNRAS</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty103</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The rotational and magnetic properties of many magnetic hot stars are poorly
characterized, therefore the MiMeS and BinaMIcS collaborations have collected
extensive high-dispersion spectropolarimetric datasets of these targets. We
present longitudinal magnetic field measurements $\langle B_{\rm z}\rangle$ for
52 early B-type stars (B5 to B0), with which we attempt to determine their
rotational periods $P_{\rm rot}$. Supplemented with high-resolution
spectroscopy, low-resolution DAO circular spectropolarimetry, and archival
Hipparcos photometry, we determined $P_{\rm rot}$ for 10 stars, leaving only 5
stars for which $P_{\rm rot}$ could not be determined. Rotational ephemerides
for 14 stars were refined via comparison of new to historical magnetic
measurements. The distribution of $P_{\rm rot}$ is very similar to that
observed for the cooler Ap/Bp stars. We also measured $v\sin{i}$ and $v_{\rm
mac}$ for all stars. Comparison to non-magnetic stars shows that $v\sin{i}$ is
much lower for magnetic stars, an expected consequence of magnetic braking. We
also find evidence that $v_{\rm mac}$ is lower for magnetic stars. LSD profiles
extracted using single-element masks revealed widespread, systematic
discrepancies in $\langle B_{\rm z}\rangle$ between different elements: this
effect is apparent only for chemically peculiar stars, suggesting it is a
consequence of chemical spots. Sinusoidal fits to H line $\langle B_{\rm
z}\rangle$ measurements (which should be minimally affected by chemical spots),
yielded evidence of surface magnetic fields more complex than simple dipoles in
6 stars for which this has not previously been reported; however, in all 6
cases the second- and third-order amplitudes are small relative to the
first-order (dipolar) amplitudes.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02928</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Wang</keyname><forenames>Haimin</forenames></author><author><keyname>Yurchyshyn</keyname><forenames>Vasyl</forenames></author><author><keyname>Liu</keyname><forenames>Chang</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ahn</keyname><forenames>Kwangsu</forenames></author><author><keyname>Toriumi</keyname><forenames>Shin</forenames></author><author><keyname>Cao</keyname><forenames>Wenda</forenames></author></authors><title>Strong Transverse Photosphere Magnetic Fields and Twist in Light Bridge
  Dividing Delta Sunspot of Active Region 12673</title><categories>astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>1 Figure, Accepted by RNAAS</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Solar Active Region (AR) 12673 is the most flare productive AR in the solar
cycle 24. It produced four X-class flares including the X9.3 flare on 06
September 2017 and the X8.2 limb event on 10 September. Sun and Norton (2017)
reported that this region had an unusual high rate of flux emergence, while
Huang et al. (2018) reported that the X9.3 flare had extremely strong
white-light flare emissions. Yang at al. (2017) described the detailed
morphological evolution of this AR. In this report, we focus on usual behaviors
of the light bridge (LB) dividing the delta configuration of this AR, namely
the strong magnetic fields (above 5500 G) in the LB and apparent photospheric
twist as shown in observations with a 0.1 arcsec spatial resolution obtained by
the 1.6m telescope at Big Bear Solar Observatory.
</abstract></arXiv>

<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.02980</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-10</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.02980</id><created>2018-01-08</created><authors><author><keyname>Niazy</keyname><forenames>Pedram</forenames></author><author><keyname>Abbassi</keyname><forenames>Amir H.</forenames></author></authors><title>An analytical approach to the CMB Polarization in a Spatially Closed
  background</title><categories>astro-ph.CO</categories><comments>14 pages, 12 figures. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with
  arXiv:1709.06549</comments><journal-ref>Physics of the dark universe 19 (2018) 36-45</journal-ref><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The scalar mode polarization of the cosmic microwave background is derived in
a spatially closed universe from the Boltzmann equation using the line of sight
integral method. The EE and TE multipole coefficients have been extracted
analytically by considering some tolerable approximations such as considering
the evolution of perturbation hydrodynamically and sudden transition from
opacity to transparency at the time of last scattering. As the major advantage
of analytic expressions, EE and TE multipole coefficients explicitly show the
dependencies on baryon density, matter density, curvature, primordial spectral
index, primordial power spectrum amplitude, Optical depth, recombination width
and recombination time. Using a realistic set of cosmological parameters taken
from a fit to data from Planck, the closed universe EE and TE power spectrums
in the scalar mode are compared with numerical results from the CAMB code and
also latest observational data. The analytic results agree with the numerical
ones on the big and moderate scales. The peak positions are in good agreement
with the numerical result on these scales while the peak heights agree with
that to within 20% due to the approximations have been considered for these
derivations. Also, several interesting properties of CMB polarization are
revealed by the analytic spectra.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03006</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-10</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>

<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03006</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Santisteban</keyname><forenames>J. V. Hernandez</forenames><affiliation>API, University of Amsterdam</affiliation><affiliation>IoA, University of Cambridge</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Cuneo</keyname><forenames>V.</forenames><affiliation>Observatorio Astronomico de Cordoba</affiliation><affiliation>CONICET</affiliation><affiliation>Instituto Argentino de Radioastronomia</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Degenaar</keyname><forenames>N.</forenames><affiliation>IoA, University of Cambridge</affiliation><affiliation>API, University of Amsterdam</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Eijnden</keyname><forenames>J. van den</forenames><affiliation>API, University of Amsterdam</affiliation><affiliation>IoA, University of Cambridge</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Altamirano</keyname><forenames>D.</forenames><affiliation>University of Southampton</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Gomez</keyname><forenames>M. N.</forenames><affiliation>Observatorio Astronomico de Cordoba</affiliation><affiliation>CONICET</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Russell</keyname><forenames>D. M.</forenames><affiliation>New York University Abu Dhabi</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Wijnands</keyname><forenames>R.</forenames><affiliation>API, University of Amsterdam</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Golovakova</keyname><forenames>R.</forenames><affiliation>New York University Abu Dhabi</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Reynolds</keyname><forenames>M. T.</forenames><affiliation>University of Michigan</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Miller</keyname><forenames>J. M.</forenames><affiliation>University of Michigan</affiliation></author></authors><title>Evidence for the ultra-compact nature of IGR J17062-6143</title><categories>astro-ph.HE</categories><comments>12 pages, 9 figures, submitted to MNRAS</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We present a multi-wavelength study of the persistent low-luminosity neutron
star low-mass X-ray binary \igr. The multi-epoch photometric UV to NIR spectral
energy distribution (SED) is consistent with an accretion disc
$F_{\nu}\propto\nu^{1/3}$. The SED modelling of the accretion disc allowed us
to estimate an outer disc radius of $R_{out}=3.9^{+1.9}_{-1.1} \times 10^{9}$
cm and a mass-transfer rate $\dot{m}=1.7^{+6.9}_{-1.2}\times10^{-9}$
M$_{\odot}$ yr$^{-1}$, consistent with both theoretical and observational
estimates of ultra-compact X-ray binaries (UCXB). In combination with empirical
X-ray/NIR relationships, we estimate the orbital period of the system to be
$\sim0.4-1$ hr. In addition, we obtained a low-resolution optical spectrum
which revealed a blue continuum and no emission lines. The lack of hydrogen in
the spectrum and the size of the accretion disc provide further evidence for an
ultra-compact nature of this system.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03020</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-10</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03020</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Spiegel</keyname><forenames>Lubov</forenames></author><author><keyname>Polyachenko</keyname><forenames>Evgeny</forenames></author></authors><title>Multiarm spirals on the periphery of disc galaxies</title><categories>astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>5 pages, 5 figures</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Spiral patterns in some disc galaxies have two arms in the centre, and three
or more arms on the periphery. The same result is also obtained in numerical
simulations of stellar and gaseous discs. We argue that such patterns may occur
due to fast cooling of the gas, resulting in formation of giant molecular
clouds. The timescale of this process is 50 Myr, the factor of 10 shorter than
of ordinary secular instability. The giant molecular clouds give rise to
multiarm spirals through the mechanism of swing amplification.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>
<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03033</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-10</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03033</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Tang</keyname><forenames>Xiaping</forenames></author></authors><title>Similarity of $\gamma$-ray spectrum in middle aged supernova remnants
  (SNRs) interacting with molecular clouds (MC): what can we learn?</title><categories>astro-ph.HE</categories><comments>Proceedings of the 7th International Fermi Symposium, Garmisch, Oct
  15-20 2017</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  In this work, we compare the $\gamma$-ray spectra available in literature
from 11 middle aged supernova remnants (SNRs) interacting with molecular clouds
(MCs). It is found that 5 remnants prefer a smoothly broken power law proton
spectrum with similar power law index but different break energy. The rest of
the SNRs need updated data to test whether a spectral break is preferred in the
proton spectrum. Then we compare the $\gamma$-ray spectra from all 11 SNRs with
the prediction from widely accepted escaping scenario and direct interaction
scenario. We show that current $\gamma$-ray data is inconsistent with the
escaping model statistically, as it predicts a diversity of $\gamma$-ray
spectra which is not detected in the observation. We also find that ambient CRs
can be very important for the $\gamma$-ray emission in the MCs external to W28
and W44, which requires further investigation. In the direct interaction
scenario, we focus on re-acceleration of pre-existing ambient CRs. The model
can produce the overall profile of $\gamma$-ray data with different
acceleration time, but it suggests a transition of seed particles in the
evolution of SNR. Whether such transition indeed exists has to be tested by
future observation. In the end, we propose that radiative SNR without MC
interaction can also produce a significant amount of $\gamma$-ray emission. One
good candidate is S147. With accumulated Fermi data and CTA in future we expect
to detect more remnants like S147.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03040</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03040</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Elias-Rosa</keyname><forenames>N.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Benetti</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Cappellaro</keyname><forenames>E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Pastorello</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Terreran</keyname><forenames>G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Morales-Garoffolo</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Howerton</keyname><forenames>S. C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Valenti</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kankare</keyname><forenames>E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Drake</keyname><forenames>A. J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Djorgovski</keyname><forenames>S. G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Tomasella</keyname><forenames>L.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Tartaglia</keyname><forenames>L.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kangas</keyname><forenames>T.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ochner</keyname><forenames>P.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Filippenko</keyname><forenames>A. V.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ciabattari</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Geier</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Howell</keyname><forenames>D. A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Isern</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Leonini</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Pignata</keyname><forenames>G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Turatto</keyname><forenames>M.</forenames></author></authors><title>SNhunt151: an explosive event inside a dense cocoon</title><categories>astro-ph.SR astro-ph.HE</categories><comments>Accepted for publication in MNRAS. 19 pages with 10 tables and 11
  figures</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty009</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  SNhunt151 was initially classified as a supernova (SN) impostor (nonterminal
outburst of a massive star). It exhibited a slow increase in luminosity,
lasting about 450 d, followed by a major brightening that reaches M_V ~ -18
mag. No source is detected to M_V &gt; -13 mag in archival images at the position
of SNhunt151 before the slow rise. Low-to-mid-resolution optical spectra
obtained during the pronounced brightening show very little evolution, being
dominated at all times by multicomponent Balmer emission lines, a signature of
interaction between the material ejected in the new outburst and the
pre-existing circumstellar medium. We also analyzed mid-infrared images from
the Spitzer Space Telescope, detecting a source at the transient position in
2014 and 2015. Overall, SNhunt151 is spectroscopically a Type IIn SN, somewhat
similar to SN2009ip. However, there are also some differences, such as a slow
pre-discovery rise, a relatively broad light-curve peak showing a longer rise
time (~ 50 d) and a slower decline, along with a negligible change in the
temperature around the peak (T &lt; 10^4 K). We suggest that SNhunt151 is the
result of an outburst, or a SN explosion, within a dense circumstellar nebula,
similar to those embedding some luminous blue variables like Eta Carinae and
originating from past mass-loss events.
</abstract></arXiv>

 <id>1801.03043</id><created>2018-01-09</created><updated>2018-01-16</updated><authors><author><keyname>Zhao</keyname><forenames>Gong-Bo</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wang</keyname><forenames>Yuting</forenames></author><author><keyname>Saito</keyname><forenames>Shun</forenames></author><author><keyname>Gil-Mar&#xed;n</keyname><forenames>H&#xe9;ctor</forenames></author><author><keyname>Percival</keyname><forenames>Will D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Tinker</keyname><forenames>Jeremy L.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Burtin</keyname><forenames>Etienne</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zarrouk</keyname><forenames>Pauline</forenames></author><author><keyname>Beutler</keyname><forenames>Florian</forenames></author><author><keyname>Baumgarten</keyname><forenames>Falk</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bautista</keyname><forenames>Julian S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hou</keyname><forenames>Jiamin</forenames></author><author><keyname>de la Macorra</keyname><forenames>Axel</forenames></author><author><keyname>Rossi</keyname><forenames>Graziano</forenames></author><author><keyname>Peacock</keyname><forenames>John A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>S&#xe1;nchez</keyname><forenames>Ariel G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Shafieloo</keyname><forenames>Arman</forenames></author><author><keyname>Schneider</keyname><forenames>Donald P.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhao</keyname><forenames>Cheng</forenames></author></authors><title>The clustering of the SDSS-IV extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic
  Survey DR14 quasar sample: a tomographic measurement of cosmic structure
  growth and expansion rate based on optimal redshift weights</title><categories>astro-ph.CO</categories><comments>16 pages, 15 figures, 5 tables; This paper is part of a set that
  analyses the eBOSS DR14 quasar sample; MNRAS submitted</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We develop a new method, which is based on the optimal redshift weighting
scheme, to extract the maximal tomographic information of baryonic acoustic
oscillations (BAO) and redshift space distortions (RSD) from the extended
Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS) Data Release 14 quasar (DR14Q)
survey. We validate our method using the EZ mocks, and apply our pipeline to
the eBOSS DR14Q sample in the redshift range of $0.8&lt;z&lt;2.2$. We report a joint
measurement of $f\sigma_8$ and two-dimensional BAO parameters $D_{\rm A}$ and
$H$ at four effective redshifts of $z_{\rm eff}=0.98, 1.23, 1.52$ and $1.94$,
and provide the full data covariance matrix. Using our measurement combined
with BOSS DR12, MGS and 6dFGS BAO measurements, we find that the existence of
dark energy is supported by observations at a $7.4\sigma$ significance level.
Combining our measurement with BOSS DR12 and Planck observations, we constrain
the gravitational growth index to be $\gamma=0.580\pm0.082$, which is fully
consistent with the prediction of general relativity. This paper is part of a
set that analyses the eBOSS DR14 quasar sample.
</abstract></arXiv>

<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03094</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Bright</keyname><forenames>J. S.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Fender</keyname><forenames>R. P.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Motta</keyname><forenames>S. E.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Mooley</keyname><forenames>K.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Perrott</keyname><forenames>Y. C.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>van Velzen</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, USA</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Carey</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Hickish</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Razavi-Ghods</keyname><forenames>N.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Titterington</keyname><forenames>D.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Scott</keyname><forenames>P.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Grainge</keyname><forenames>K.</forenames><affiliation>Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, University of Manchester, Manchester, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Scaife</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames><affiliation>Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, University of Manchester, Manchester, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Cantwell</keyname><forenames>T.</forenames><affiliation>Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, University of Manchester, Manchester, UK</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Rumsey</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames><affiliation>Astrophysics Group, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge, UK</affiliation></author></authors><title>Long-term radio and X-ray evolution of the tidal disruption event
  ASASSN-14li</title><categories>astro-ph.HE</categories><comments>11 pages, 3 figures, accepted for publication in MNRAS</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty077</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We report on late time radio and X-ray observations of the tidal disruption
event candidate ASASSN-14li, covering the first 1000 days of the decay phase.
For the first $\sim200$ days the radio and X-ray emission fade in concert. This
phase is better fit by an exponential decay at X-ray wavelengths, while the
radio emission is well described by either an exponential or the canonical
$t^{-5/3}$ decay assumed for tidal disruption events. The correlation between
radio and X-ray emission during this period can be fit as $L_{R}\propto
L_{X}^{1.9\pm0.2}$. After 400 days the radio emission at $15.5\,\textrm{GHz}$
has reached a plateau level of $244\pm8\,\mu\textrm{Jy}$ which it maintains for
at least the next 600 days, while the X-ray emission continues to fade
exponentially. This steady level of radio emission is likely due to relic radio
lobes from the weak AGN-like activity implied by historical radio observations.
We note that while most existing models are based upon the evolution of ejecta
which are decoupled from the central black hole, the radio : X-ray correlation
during the declining phase is also consistent with core jet emission coupled to
a radiatively efficient accretion flow.
</abstract></arXiv>

<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03100</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03100</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Mastroserio</keyname><forenames>Guglielmo</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ingram</keyname><forenames>Adam</forenames></author><author><keyname>van der Klis</keyname><forenames>Michiel</forenames></author></authors><title>Multi-timescale X-ray reverberation mapping of accreting black holes</title><categories>astro-ph.HE</categories><comments>Accepted for publication in MNRAS</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty075</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Accreting black holes show characteristic reflection features in their X-ray
spectrum, including an iron K$\alpha$ line, resulting from hard X-ray continuum
photons illuminating the accretion disk. The reverberation lag resulting from
the path length difference between direct and reflected emission provides a
powerful tool to probe the innermost regions around both stellar-mass and
supermassive black holes. Here, we present for the first time a reverberation
mapping formalism that enables modeling of energy dependent time lags and
variability amplitude for a wide range of variability timescales, taking the
complete information of the cross-spectrum into account. We use a pivoting
power-law model to account for the spectral variability of the continuum that
dominates over the reverberation lags for longer time scale variability. We use
an analytic approximation to self-consistently account for the non-linear
effects caused by this continuum spectral variability, which have been ignored
by all previous reverberation studies. We find that ignoring these non-linear
effects can bias measurements of the reverberation lags, particularly at low
frequencies. Since our model is analytic, we are able to fit simultaneously for
a wide range of Fourier frequencies without prohibitive computational expense.
We also introduce a formalism of fitting to real and imaginary parts of our
cross-spectrum statistic, which naturally avoids some mistakes/inaccuracies
previously common in the literature. We perform proof-of-principle fits to
Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer data of Cygnus X-1.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>
<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03102</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03102</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Fleming</keyname><forenames>Brian</forenames></author><author><keyname>Quijada</keyname><forenames>Manuel</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hennessy</keyname><forenames>John</forenames></author><author><keyname>Egan</keyname><forenames>Arika</forenames></author><author><keyname>Del Hoyo</keyname><forenames>Javier</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hicks</keyname><forenames>Brian A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wiley</keyname><forenames>James</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kruczek</keyname><forenames>Nicholas</forenames></author><author><keyname>Erickson</keyname><forenames>Nicholas</forenames></author><author><keyname>France</keyname><forenames>Kevin</forenames></author></authors><title>Advanced Environmentally Resistant Lithium Fluoride Mirror Coatings for
  the Next-Generation of Broadband Space Observatories</title><categories>astro-ph.IM</categories><comments>Published by the Optical Society of America in Applied Optics</comments><journal-ref>Brian Fleming, Manuel Quijada, et al., &quot;Advanced environmentally
  resistant lithium fluoride mirror coatings for the next generation of
  broadband space observatories,&quot; Appl. Opt. 56, 9941-9950 (2017)</journal-ref><doi>10.1364/AO.56.009941</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Recent advances in the physical vapor deposition (PVD) of protective fluoride
films have raised the far-ultraviolet (FUV: 912-1600 {\AA}) reflectivity of
aluminum-based mirrors closer to the theoretical limit. The greatest gains, at
more than 20%, have come for lithium fluoride-protected aluminum, which has the
shortest wavelength cutoff of any conventional overcoat. Despite the success of
the NASA FUSE mission, the use of lithium fluoride (LiF)-based optics is rare,
as LiF is hygroscopic and requires handling procedures that can drive risk.
With NASA now studying two large mission concepts for astronomy, Large
UV-Optical-IR Surveyor (LUVOIR) and the Habitable Exoplanet Imaging Mission
(HabEx), which mandate throughput down to 1000 {\AA}, the development of
LiF-based coatings becomes crucial. This paper discusses steps that are being
taken to qualify these new enhanced LiF-protected aluminum (eLiF) mirror
coatings for flight. In addition to quantifying the hygroscopic degradation, we
have developed a new method of protecting eLiF with an ultrathin (10-20 {\AA})
capping layer of a non-hygroscopic material to increase durability. We report
on the performance of eLiF-based optics and assess the steps that need to be
taken to qualify such coatings for LUVOIR, HabEx, and other FUV-sensitive space
missions.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03103</identifier>

<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03103</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Salmon</keyname><forenames>Brett</forenames></author><author><keyname>Coe</keyname><forenames>Dan</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bradley</keyname><forenames>Larry</forenames></author><author><keyname>Brada&#x10d;</keyname><forenames>Marusa</forenames></author><author><keyname>Huang</keyname><forenames>Kuang-Han</forenames></author><author><keyname>Strait</keyname><forenames>Victoria</forenames></author><author><keyname>Oesch</keyname><forenames>Pascal</forenames></author><author><keyname>Paterno-Mahler</keyname><forenames>Rachel</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zitrin</keyname><forenames>Adi</forenames></author><author><keyname>Acebron</keyname><forenames>Ana</forenames></author><author><keyname>Cibirka</keyname><forenames>Nath&#xe1;lia</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kikuchihara</keyname><forenames>Shotaro</forenames></author><author><keyname>Oguri</keyname><forenames>Masamune</forenames></author><author><keyname>Brammer</keyname><forenames>Gabriel B.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sharon</keyname><forenames>Keren</forenames></author><author><keyname>Trenti</keyname><forenames>Michele</forenames></author><author><keyname>Avila</keyname><forenames>Roberto L.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hoag</keyname><forenames>Austin</forenames></author><author><keyname>Jones</keyname><forenames>Christine</forenames></author><author><keyname>Mainali</keyname><forenames>Ramesh</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ouchi</keyname><forenames>Masami</forenames></author><author><keyname>Rodney</keyname><forenames>Steven A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Stark</keyname><forenames>Daniel</forenames></author><author><keyname>Umetsu</keyname><forenames>Keiichi</forenames></author></authors><title>A Candidate $z\sim10$ Galaxy Strongly Lensed into a Spatially Resolved
  Arc</title><categories>astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>7 pages, 4 figures. Submitted to ApJ Letters</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The most distant galaxies known are at z~10-11, observed 400-500 Myr after
the Big Bang. The few z~10-11 candidates discovered to date have been
exceptionally small- barely resolved, if at all, by the Hubble Space Telescope.
Here we present the discovery of SPT0615-JD, a fortuitous z~10
(z_phot=9.9+/-0.6) galaxy candidate stretched into an arc over ~2.5&quot; by the
effects of strong gravitational lensing. Discovered in the Reionization Lensing
Cluster Survey (RELICS) Hubble Treasury program and companion S-RELICS Spitzer
program, this candidate has a lensed H-band magnitude of 25.7+/-0.1 AB mag.
With a magnification of \mu~4-7 estimated from our lens models, the de-lensed
intrinsic magnitude is 27.6+/-0.3 AB mag, and the half-light radius is r_e&lt;0.8
kpc, both consistent with other z&gt;9 candidates. The inferred stellar mass (log
[M* /M_Sun]=9.7^{+0.7}_{-0.5}) and star formation rate (\log [SFR/M_Sun
yr^{-1}]=1.3^{+0.2}_{-0.3}) indicate that this candidate is a typical
star-forming galaxy on the z&gt;6 SFR-M* relation. We note that three independent
lens models predict two counterimages, at least one of which should be of a
similar magnitude to the arc, but these counterimages are not yet detected.
Counterimages would not be expected if the arc were at lower redshift. However,
the only spectral energy distributions capable of fitting the Hubble and
Spitzer photometry well at lower redshifts require unphysical combinations of
z~2 galaxy properties. The unprecedented lensed size of this z~10 candidate
offers the potential for the James Webb Space Telescope to study the geometric
and kinematic properties of a galaxy observed 500 Myr after the Big Bang.
</abstract></arXiv>

<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03105</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03105</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Cormier</keyname><forenames>D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bigiel</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Jim&#xe9;nez-Donaire</keyname><forenames>M. J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Leroy</keyname><forenames>A. K.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Gallagher</keyname><forenames>M.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Usero</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sandstrom</keyname><forenames>K.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bolatto</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hughes</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kramer</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Krumholz</keyname><forenames>M. R.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Meier</keyname><forenames>D. S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Murphy</keyname><forenames>E. J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Pety</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Rosolowsky</keyname><forenames>E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Schinnerer</keyname><forenames>E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Schruba</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sliwa</keyname><forenames>K.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Walter</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author></authors><title>Full-disc $^{13}$CO(1-0) mapping across nearby galaxies of the EMPIRE
  survey and the CO-to-H$_2$ conversion factor</title><categories>astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>accepted for publication in MNRAS</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty059</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Carbon monoxide (CO) provides crucial information about the molecular gas
properties of galaxies. While $^{12}$CO has been targeted extensively,
isotopologues such as $^{13}$CO have the advantage of being less optically
thick and observations have recently become accessible across full galaxy
discs. We present a comprehensive new dataset of $^{13}$CO(1-0) observations
with the IRAM 30-m telescope of the full discs of 9 nearby spiral galaxies from
the EMPIRE survey at a spatial resolution of $\sim$1.5kpc. $^{13}$CO(1-0) is
mapped out to $0.7-1r_{25}$ and detected at high signal-to-noise throughout our
maps. We analyse the $^{12}$CO(1-0)-to-$^{13}$CO(1-0) ratio ($\Re$) as a
function of galactocentric radius and other parameters such as the
$^{12}$CO(2-1)-to-$^{12}$CO(1-0) intensity ratio, the 70-to-160$\mu$m flux
density ratio, the star-formation rate surface density, the star-formation
efficiency, and the CO-to-H$_2$ conversion factor. We find that $\Re$ varies by
a factor of 2 at most within and amongst galaxies, with a median value of 11
and larger variations in the galaxy centres than in the discs. We argue that
optical depth effects, most likely due to changes in the mixture of
diffuse/dense gas, are favored explanations for the observed $\Re$ variations,
while abundance changes may also be at play. We calculate a spatially-resolved
$^{13}$CO(1-0)-to-H$_2$ conversion factor and find an average value of
$1.0\times10^{21}$ cm$^{-2}$ (K.km/s)$^{-1}$ over our sample with a standard
deviation of a factor of 2. We find that $^{13}$CO(1-0) does not appear to be a
good predictor of the bulk molecular gas mass in normal galaxy discs due to the
presence of a large diffuse phase, but it may be a better tracer of the mass
than $^{12}$CO(1-0) in the galaxy centres where the fraction of dense gas is
larger.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>

H.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sab&#xed;n-Sanjuli&#xe1;n</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Sim&#xf3;n-D&#xed;az</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Tramper</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Crowther</keyname><forenames>P. L.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Garcia</keyname><forenames>M.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Gieles</keyname><forenames>M.</forenames></author><author><keyname>H&#xe9;nault-Brunet</keyname><forenames>V.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Herrero</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Izzard</keyname><forenames>R. G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Kalari</keyname><forenames>V.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Lennon</keyname><forenames>D. J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Apell&#xe1;niz</keyname><forenames>J. Ma&#xed;z</forenames></author><author><keyname>Markova</keyname><forenames>N.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Najarro</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Podsiadlowski</keyname><forenames>Ph.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Puls</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Taylor</keyname><forenames>W. D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>van Loon</keyname><forenames>J. Th.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Vink</keyname><forenames>J. S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Norman</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames></author></authors><title>An excess of massive stars in the local 30 Doradus starburst</title><categories>astro-ph.SR astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>Authors' version of paper published in Science at
  http://science.sciencemag.org/content/359/6371/69 ; 15 pages main text (3
  figures), 47 pages supplementary materials (10 figures, 3 tables)</comments><journal-ref>Science 359, 69 (2018)</journal-ref><doi>10.1126/science.aan0106</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The 30 Doradus star-forming region in the Large Magellanic Cloud is a nearby
analogue of large star-formation events in the distant Universe. We determine
the recent formation history and the initial mass function (IMF) of massive
stars in 30 Doradus based on spectroscopic observations of 247 stars more
massive than 15 solar masses ($\mathrm{M}_\odot$). The main episode of massive
star formation started about $8\,\mathrm{Myr}$ ago and the star-formation rate
seems to have declined in the last $1\,\mathrm{Myr}$. The IMF is densely
sampled up to $200\,\mathrm{M}_\odot$ and contains $32\pm12\%$ more stars above
$30\,\mathrm{M}_\odot$ than predicted by a standard Salpeter IMF. In the mass
range $15-200\,\mathrm{M}_\odot$, the IMF power-law exponent is
$1.90^{+0.37}_{-0.26}$, shallower than the Salpeter value of 2.35.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03121</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03121</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Lamberts</keyname><forenames>Astrid</forenames></author></authors><title>Merging massive black holes: the right place and the right time</title><categories>astro-ph.GA</categories><comments>Proceeding of IAU Symposium 338 : &quot;Gravitational Waves Astrophysics :
  Early results from GW searches and EM counterparts&quot;</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The LIGO/Virgo detections of gravitational waves from merging black holes of
$\simeq$ 30 solar mass suggest progenitor stars of low metallicity
(Z/Z$_{\odot} \lesssim 0.3$). In this talk I will provide constrains on where
the progenitors of GW150914 and GW170104 may have formed, based on advanced
models of galaxy formation and evolution combined with binary population
synthesis models. First I will combine estimates of galaxy properties
(star-forming gas metallicity, star formation rate and merger rate) across
cosmic time to predict the low redshift BBH merger rate as a function of
present day host galaxy mass, formation redshift of the progenitor system and
different progenitor metallicities. I will show that the signal is dominated by
binaries formed at the peak of star formation in massive galaxies with and
binaries formed recently in dwarf galaxies. Then, I will present what very high
resolution hydrodynamic simulations of different galaxy types can learn us
about their black hole populations.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03128</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03128</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Liu</keyname><forenames>Xiaodong</forenames></author><author><keyname>Schmidt</keyname><forenames>J&#xfc;rgen</forenames></author></authors><title>Dust arcs in the region of Jupiter's Trojan asteroids</title><categories>astro-ph.EP</categories><comments>6 pages, 7 figures</comments><journal-ref>Xiaodong Liu and J\&quot;urgen Schmidt, 2018, A&amp;A, 609, A57</journal-ref><doi>10.1051/0004-6361/201730951</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Aims. The surfaces of the Trojan asteroids are steadily bombarded by
interplanetary micrometeoroids, which releases ejecta of small dust particles.
These particles form the faint dust arcs that are associated with asteroid
clouds. Here we analyze the particle dynamics and structure of the arc in the
region of the $L_4$ Trojan asteroids.
  Methods. We calculate the total cross section of the $L_4$ Trojan asteroids
and the production rate of dust particles. The motion of the particles is
perturbed by a variety of forces. We simulate the dynamical evolution of the
dust particles, and explore the overall features of the Trojan dust arc.
  Results. The simulations show that the arc is mainly composed of grains in
the size range 4-10 microns. Compared to the $L_4$ Trojan asteroids, the dust
arc is distributed more widely in the azimuthal direction, extending to a range
of [30,120] degrees relative to Jupiter. The peak number density does not
develop at $L_4$. There exist two peaks that are azimuthally displaced from
$L_4$.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>

<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03136</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03136</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Niembro</keyname><forenames>Tatiana</forenames></author><author><keyname>Lara</keyname><forenames>Alejandro</forenames></author><author><keyname>Gonz&#xe1;lez</keyname><forenames>Ricardo F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Cant&#xf3;</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author></authors><title>Numerical simulations of ICME-ICME interactions</title><categories>astro-ph.SR</categories><license>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/</license><abstract>  We present hydrodynamical simulations of interacting Coronal Mass Ejections
in the Interplanetary medium (ICMEs). In these events, two consecutive CMEs are
launched from the Sun in similar directions within an interval of time of a few
hours. In our numerical model, we assume that the ambient solar wind is
characterized by its velocity and mass-loss rate. Then, the CMEs are generated
when the flow velocity and mass-loss rate suddenly change, with respect to the
ambient solar wind conditions during two intervals of time, which correspond to
the durations of the CMEs. After their interaction, a merged region is formed
and evolve as a single structure into the interplanetary medium. In this work,
we are interested in the general morphology of this merged region, which
depends on the initial parameters of the ambient solar wind and each of the
CMEs involved. In order to understand this morphology, we have performed a
parametric study in which we characterize the effects of the initial parameters
variations on the density and velocity profiles at 1 AU, using as reference the
well-documented event of July 25th, 2004. Based on this parametrization we were
able to reproduce with a high accuracy the observed profiles. Then, we apply
the parametrization results to the interaction events of May 23, 2010; August
1, 2010; and November 9, 2012. With this approach and using values for the
input parameters within the CME observational errors, our simulated profiles
reproduce the main features observed at 1 AU. Even though we do not take into
account the magnetic field, our models give a physical insight into the
propagation and interaction of ICMEs.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03146</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03146</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Kane</keyname><forenames>Stephen R.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Arney</keyname><forenames>Giada</forenames></author><author><keyname>Crisp</keyname><forenames>David</forenames></author><author><keyname>Domagal-Goldman</keyname><forenames>Shawn</forenames></author><author><keyname>Glaze</keyname><forenames>Lori S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Goldblatt</keyname><forenames>Colin</forenames></author><author><keyname>Lenardic</keyname><forenames>Adrian</forenames></author><author><keyname>Unterborn</keyname><forenames>Cayman</forenames></author><author><keyname>Way</keyname><forenames>Michael J.</forenames></author></authors><title>Venus: The Making of an Uninhabitable World</title><categories>astro-ph.EP</categories><comments>6 pages, 1 figure, white paper submitted in response to the
  solicitation of feedback for the &quot;Astrobiology Science Strategy for the
  Search for Life in the Universe&quot; by the National Academy of Sciences</comments><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  The goals of the astrobiology community are focussed on developing a
framework for the detection of biosignatures, or evidence thereof, on objects
inside and outside of our solar system. A fundamental aspect of understanding
the limits of habitable environments and detectable signatures is the study of
where the boundaries of such environments can occur. Thus, the need to study
the creation, evolution, and frequency of hostile environments for habitability
is an integral part of the astrobiology story. These provide the opportunity to
understand the bifurcation, between habitable and uninhabitable. The archetype
of such a planet is the Earth's sister planet, Venus, and provides a unique
opportunity to explore the processes that created a completely uninhabitable
environment and thus define the conditions that can rule out bio-related
signatures. We advocate a continued comprehensive study of our sister planet,
including models of early atmospheres, compositional abundances, and
Venus-analog frequency analysis from current and future exoplanet data.
Moreover, new missions to Venus to provide in-situ data are necessary.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>
<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03167</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-24</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03167</id><created>2018-01-08</created><authors><author><keyname>Huang</keyname><forenames>F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wang</keyname><forenames>X. -F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hosseinzadeh</keyname><forenames>G.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Brown</keyname><forenames>P. J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Mo</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhang</keyname><forenames>J. -J.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhang</keyname><forenames>K. -C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Zhang</keyname><forenames>T. -M.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Howell</keyname><forenames>D. -A.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Arcavi</keyname><forenames>I.</forenames></author><author><keyname>McCully</keyname><forenames>C.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Valenti</keyname><forenames>S.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Rui</keyname><forenames>L. -M.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Song</keyname><forenames>H.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Xiang</keyname><forenames>D. -F.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Li</keyname><forenames>W. -X.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Lin</keyname><forenames>H.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wang</keyname><forenames>L. -F.</forenames></author></authors><title>SN 2016X: A Type II-P Supernova with A Signature of Shock Breakout from
  Explosion of A Massive Red Supergiant</title><categories>astro-ph.HE astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>18 pages, 12 figures, MNRAS accepted</comments><doi>10.1093/mnras/sty066</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We present extensive ultraviolet (UV) and optical photometry, as well as
dense optical spectroscopy for type II Plateau (IIP) supernova SN 2016X that
exploded in the nearby ($\sim$ 15 Mpc) spiral galaxy UGC 08041. The
observations span the period from 2 to 180 days after the explosion; in
particular, the Swift UV data probably captured the signature of shock breakout
associated with the explosion of SN 2016X. It shows very strong UV emission
during the first week after explosion, with contribution of $\sim$ 20 -- 30% to
the bolometric luminosity (versus $\lesssim$ 15% for normal SNe IIP). Moreover,
we found that this supernova has an unusually long rise time of about 12.6
$\pm$ 0.5 days in the $R$ band (versus $\sim$ 7.0 days for typical SNe IIP).
The optical light curves and spectral evolution are quite similar to the
fast-declining type IIP object SN 2013ej, except that SN 2016X has a relatively
brighter tail. Based on the evolution of photospheric temperature as inferred
from the $Swift$ data in the early phase, we derive that the progenitor of SN
2016X has a radius of about 930 $\pm$ 70 R$_{\odot}$. This large-size star is
expected to be a red supergiant star with an initial mass of $\gtrsim$ 19 -- 20
M$_{\odot}$ based on the mass $--$ radius relation of the Galactic red
supergiants, and it represents one of the most largest and massive progenitors
found for SNe IIP.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03171</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03171</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Xu</keyname><forenames>Yan</forenames></author><author><keyname>Cao</keyname><forenames>Wenda</forenames></author><author><keyname>Ahn</keyname><forenames>Kwangsu</forenames></author><author><keyname>Jing</keyname><forenames>Ju</forenames></author><author><keyname>Liu</keyname><forenames>Chang</forenames></author><author><keyname>Chae</keyname><forenames>Jongchul</forenames></author><author><keyname>Huang</keyname><forenames>Nengyi</forenames></author><author><keyname>Deng</keyname><forenames>Na</forenames></author><author><keyname>Gary</keyname><forenames>Dale E.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Wang</keyname><forenames>Haimin</forenames></author></authors><title>Transient rotation of photospheric vector magnetic fields associated
  with a solar flare</title><categories>astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>http://rdcu.be/Epb8</comments><doi>10.1038/s41467-017-02509-w</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  As one of the most violent eruptions on the Sun, flares are believed to be
powered by magnetic reconnection. The fundamental physics involving the
release, transfer and deposition of energy have been studied extensively.
Taking advantage of the unprecedented resolution provided by the 1.6-m Goode
Solar Telescope, here we show a sudden rotation of vector magnetic fields,
about 12$^{\circ}$-20$^{\circ}$ counterclockwise, associated with a flare.
Unlike the permanent changes reported previously, the azimuth-angle change is
transient and co-spatial/temporal with H$\alpha$ emission. The measured azimuth
angle becomes closer to that in potential fields suggesting untwist of flare
loops. The magnetograms were obtained in the near infrared at 1.56~$\mu$m,
which is minimally affected by flare emission and no intensity profile change
was detected. We believe that these transient changes are real and discuss the
possible explanations in which the high energy electron beams or
$Alfv\acute{e}n$ waves play a crucial role.
</abstract></arXiv>

L.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Vikram</keyname><forenames>V.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Vivas</keyname><forenames>A. K.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>ker</keyname><forenames>A. R. Wal</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Wechsler</keyname><forenames>R. H.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Weller</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Wester</keyname><forenames>W.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Wolf</keyname><forenames>R. C.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Wu</keyname><forenames>H.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Yanny</keyname><forenames>B.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Zenteno</keyname><forenames>A.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Zhang</keyname><forenames>Y.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author><author><keyname>Zuntz</keyname><forenames>J.</forenames><affiliation>DES Collaboration</affiliation></author></authors><title>The Dark Energy Survey Data Release 1</title><categories>astro-ph.IM astro-ph.CO astro-ph.GA astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>28 pages, 19 Figures. Release page found at this url
  https://des.ncsa.illinois.edu/releases/dr1</comments><report-no>FERMILAB-PUB-17-603-AE-E</report-no><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  We describe the first public data release of the Dark Energy Survey, DES DR1,
consisting of reduced single epoch images, coadded images, coadded source
catalogs, and associated products and services assembled over the first three
years of DES science operations. DES DR1 is based on optical/near-infrared
imaging from 345 distinct nights (August 2013 to February 2016) by the Dark
Energy Camera mounted on the 4-m Blanco telescope at Cerro Tololo
Inter-American Observatory in Chile. We release data from the DES wide-area
survey covering ~5,000 sq. deg. of the southern Galactic cap in five broad
photometric bands, grizY. DES DR1 has a median delivered point-spread function
of g = 1.12, r = 0.96, i = 0.88, z = 0.84, and Y = 0.90 arcsec FWHM, a
photometric precision of &lt; 1% in all bands, and an astrometric precision of 151
mas. The median coadded catalog depth for a 1.95&quot; diameter aperture at S/N = 10
is g = 24.33, r = 24.08, i = 23.44, z = 22.69, and Y = 21.44 mag. DES DR1
includes nearly 400M distinct astronomical objects detected in ~10,000 coadd
tiles of size 0.534 sq. deg. produced from ~39,000 individual exposures.
Benchmark galaxy and stellar samples contain ~310M and ~ 80M objects,
respectively, following a basic object quality selection. These data are
accessible through a range of interfaces, including query web clients, image
cutout servers, jupyter notebooks, and an interactive coadd image visualization
tool. DES DR1 constitutes the largest photometric data set to date at the
achieved depth and photometric precision.
</abstract></arXiv>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03196</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03196</id><created>2018-01-09</created><authors><author><keyname>Zhang</keyname><forenames>Xianfei</forenames></author><author><keyname>Liu</keyname><forenames>Jinzhong</forenames></author><author><keyname>Jeffery</keyname><forenames>C. Simon</forenames></author><author><keyname>Hall</keyname><forenames>Philip D.</forenames></author><author><keyname>Bi</keyname><forenames>Shaolan</forenames></author></authors><title>The double helium-white dwarf channel for the formation of AM CVn
  binaries</title><categories>astro-ph.SR</categories><comments>17 pages, 9 figures, published in Research in Astronomy and
  Astrophysics (RAA)</comments><doi>10.1088/1674-4527/18/1/9</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Most close double helium white dwarfs will merge within a Hubble time due to
orbital decay by gravitational-wave radiation. However, a significant fraction
with low mass ratios will survive for a long time as a consequence of stable
mass transfer. Such stable mass transfer between two helium white dwarfs (HeWD)
provides one channel for the production of AM\,CVn binary stars. In previous
calculations of double HeWD progenitors, the accreting HeWD was treated as a
point mass. We have computed the evolution of 16 double HeWD models in order to
investigate the consequences of treating the detailed evolution of both
components. We find that the boundary between binaries having stable and
unstable mass transfer is slightly modified by this approach. By comparing with
observed periods and mass ratios, we redetermine masses of eight known AM\,CVn
stars by our double HeWDs channel, i.e. HM\,Cnc, AM CVn, V406\,Hya, J0926,
J1240, GP\,Com, Gaia14aae and V396\,Hya. We propose that central spikes in the
triple-peaked emission spectra of J1240, GP\,Com and V396\,Hya and the surface
abundance ratios of N/C/O in GP\,Com can be explained by the stable double HeWD
channel. The mass estimates derived from our calculations are used to discuss
the predicted gravitational wave signal in the context of the Laser
Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA).
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>
<record>
<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03262</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03262</id><created>2018-01-10</created><authors><author><keyname>Dietrich</keyname><forenames>Wieland</forenames></author><author><keyname>Jones</keyname><forenames>Chris. A.</forenames></author></authors><title>Anelastic spherical dynamos with radially variable electrical
  conductivity</title><categories>astro-ph.EP</categories><doi>10.1016/j.icarus.2018.01.003</doi><license>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</license><abstract>  A series of numerical simulations of the dynamo process operating inside gas
giant planets has been performed. We use an anelastic, fully nonlinear,
three-dimensional, benchmarked MHD code to evolve the flow, entropy and
magnetic field. Our models take into account the varying electrical
conductivity, high in the ionised metallic hydrogen region, low in the
molecular outer region. Our suite of electrical conductivity profiles ranges
from Jupiter-like, where the outer hydrodynamic region is quite thin, to
Saturn-like, where there is a thick non-conducting shell. The rapid rotation
leads to the formation of two distinct dynamical regimes which are separated by
a magnetic tangent cylinder - mTC. Outside the mTC there are strong zonal
flows, where Reynolds stress balances turbulent viscosity, but inside the mTC
Lorentz force reduces the zonal flow. The dynamic interaction between both
regions induces meridional circulation. We find a rich diversity of magnetic
field morphologies. There are Jupiter-like steady dipolar fields, and a belt of
quadrupolar dominated dynamos spanning the range of models between Jupiter-like
and Saturn-like conductivity profiles. This diversity may be linked to the
appearance of reversed sign helicity in the metallic regions of our dynamos.
With Saturn-like conductivity profiles we find models with dipolar magnetic
fields, whose axisymmetric components resemble those of Saturn, and which
oscillate on a very long time-scale. However, the non-axisymmetric field
components of our models are at least ten times larger than those of Saturn,
possibly due to the absence of any stably stratified layer.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
</record>

<header>
 <identifier>oai:arXiv.org:1801.03272</identifier>
 <datestamp>2018-01-11</datestamp>
 <setSpec>physics:astro-ph</setSpec>
</header>
<metadata>
 <arXiv xmlns="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv/ http://arxiv.org/OAI/arXiv.xsd">
 <id>1801.03272</id><created>2018-01-10</created><authors><author><keyname>Hossain</keyname><forenames>Md. Wali</forenames></author></authors><title>Quintessential inflation: A unified scenario of inflation and dark
  energy</title><categories>gr-qc astro-ph.CO</categories><comments>5 pages, 5 figures, Based on the talk given at the Joint
  International Conference of ICGAC-XIII and IK-15 on Gravitation, Astrophysics
  and Cosmology held at Ewha Womans University, Seoul, Korea (July 3-7, 2017),
  Published in EPJ Web of Conferences</comments><journal-ref>EPJ Web of Conferences 168, 04007 (2018)</journal-ref><doi>10.1051/epjconf/201816804007</doi><license>http://arxiv.org/licenses/nonexclusive-distrib/1.0/</license><abstract>  Quintessential inflation unifies inflation and late time acceleration by a
single scalar field. Such a scenario, with canonical and non-canonical scalar
fields, has been discussed . The scalar field behaves as an inflaton field
during inflation and as a quintessence field during late time. Also the
predictions of the models has been compared with the recent Planck data.
</abstract></arXiv>
</metadata>
